turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You look good.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: You look good yourself.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I thought you were never going to call me.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You did?

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I really wanted you to call me, and I thought you were never going to --

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You could have called me --

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: No way.  No way I was going to be the first woman you went out with after...  There is no percentage whatsoever in being the first woman anyone goes out with after...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You <u>are</u> the first woman I'm going out with.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: So whatdya say? I'll get the check, and I'll call you in eight months.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: We can't finish the job.  She's on her sixth painter, now she's thinking maybe she wants the fireplace rebricked --

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I know her pretty well.  Maybe I could call her --

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I've already solved it.  I've hired a hit man.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Is he there?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No.  After he was born, every time we started to make love, he would cry.  He had an uncanny sense of timing.  We really shouldn't do anything here anyway.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Absolutely.  Right.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: He's ten.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: He's good at it.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I read an article about this ...

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I read the same article...

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: It takes time --

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Absolutely.  When I come back, maybe the two of us should spend some time together, on our own.  What do you think?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Sure.  Sure.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: I told you it would happen. It's bound to happen when a man works alone!

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Why didn't you give a warning signal?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Your foreman says that's a foreman's job.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Want to go up to your office, Mr. Alexander?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Naturally. You think I parked here for a cup of coffee?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You're welcome to one.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: No thanks.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: The men would like to know who this gentleman is.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: That's none of their affair.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I mean it. I know your work record. You were in line for foreman when this trouble started -- did you know that? You had a real future with this company, but you let those Reds stir you up. And now they'll sell you down the river. Why don't you wake up, Ray?  That's your name, isn't it, Ray?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: No. My name is Quintero. Mister Quintero.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Are you going to let us pass -- or do I have to call the Sheriff?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: There's nothing stopping you.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Mornin'.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: How's it going?

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Well, those new fellows you hired from out of town -- we brought 'em up here in a truck this morning, but they took one look at that picket line and turned tail.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Not so sure about that. Letter of the Law, you know. All the injunction says is no picketing by miners.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Whose side are you on anyway?

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Now don't get excited, Mr. Alexander. They'll scatter like a covey of quail.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: I've tried everything but shootin' 'em down.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You haven't tried locking them up!

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: You want 'em all arrested?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: No, just the ring leaders. The fire-eaters. And the ones with big families ...  Barton -- where's that boy?

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Got any more ideas?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I don't make policy.

turns.speaker: ANTONIO
turns.text: Take a drink. Calm down!

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: I say we gotta take action. Now.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Now why don't you let these gentlemen pass? Don't you know who's in that car?

turns.speaker: ANTONIO
turns.text: It's the paymaster from Moscow -- with our gold.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: No, no, it's the president of the company himself -- come all the way out here to make Jenkins general manager. So why you acting so mean?

turns.speaker: ANTONIO
turns.text: Jenkins ain't no boss.  Mean we're gonna let people like Jenkins stay here?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You can't send him back to Oklahoma. It'd be inhumane.

turns.speaker: ANTONIO
turns.text: How goes it?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: It never ends.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Three hours! Just to heat enough water to wash this stuff!  I tell you something. If this strike is ever settled -- which I doubt -- I don't go back to work unless the company installs hot running water for us.  It should've been a union demand from the beginning.

turns.speaker: ANTONIO
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ANTONIO
turns.text: It's like Charley Vidal says -- there's two kinds of slavery, wage slavery and domestic slavery. The Woman Question, he calls it.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: The woman question?

turns.speaker: ANTONIO
turns.text: Question, question -- the problem, what to do about 'em.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: So? What does he want to do about 'em?

turns.speaker: ANTONIO
turns.text: He says give 'em equality. Equality in jobs, equality in the home. Also sex equality.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: What do you mean -- sex equality?

turns.speaker: ANTONIO
turns.text: You know ...  What's good for the goose is good for the gander.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Hear you had a little trouble, Quintero. Defective fuse?  Well, you're all in one piece. So what's the beef?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You know the beef. This new rule of yours, that we work alone. We're taking it up with the Super.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Super's busy -- with your Negotiatin' Committee.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: So much the better.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Now wait a minute. Super's the one made the rule. He ain't gonna give you no helper.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: He will if he wants us to go on blasting.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Foreman wants to get the ore out. Miner wants to get his brothers out. In one piece.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: You work alone, savvy? You can't handle the job, I'll find someone who can.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Who? A scab?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: An American.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I checked the drift just before he blasted. It was all clear ... The man must have been asleep or something.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You weren't even there. You were back at the station. Kalinsky told me ...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: You're a liar, Pancho. A no-good, dirty ...

turns.speaker: ESTELLA
turns.text: Are you sick, Mama?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: No, Estellita.

turns.speaker: ESTELLA
turns.text: Are you sad?  Are we going to church? For your confession?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Later. When I finish the ironing.

turns.speaker: ESTELLA
turns.text: Mama, can I put the candles ...

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Hush... not a word about the cake, hear?

turns.speaker: ESTELLA
turns.text: Why are they singing, Mama?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: They are singing for me.

turns.speaker: ESTELLA
turns.text: Can we light the candles now? On the cake?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Yes. We will light the candles.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: To the mine?

turns.speaker: TERESA
turns.text: Sure. Where they're negotiating. In the company office. We'll go up there and picket the place.

turns.speaker: TERESA
turns.text: Come on, Esperanza -- how about it? We got to.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: No. No. I can't. If Ramón ever found me on a picket line ...

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: He can't drink this milk. It'll make him sick. He's on a formula.  I was a fool! I shouldn't have kept him with me.

turns.speaker: TERESA
turns.text: Don't you worry. We'll get some action.

turns.speaker: TERESA
turns.text: It's all set. Consuelo's squad can take they day off tomorrow. We're taking over.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Good. Come in, we'll work it out. Sit down, sit down.

turns.speaker: TERESA
turns.text: So they had a little taste of what its like to be a woman ... and they run away.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: With Ramón it's ... pride. I spoke out of the bitterness in me. And he was hurt.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: We're only one payment behind. I argued with her. It isn't right.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: It isn't right, she says. Was it right that we bought this ... this instrument?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: But you had to have it, didn't you? It was so nice to listen

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: I listen to it. Every night. When you're out to the beer parlor.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Where you going?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Got to talk to the brothers.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: This water's cold again.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: I'm sorry. The fire's gone out.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Forget it.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Forget it? I chop wood for the stove five times a day. Every time I remember. I remember that across the tracks the Anglo miners have hot water in pipes. And bathrooms. Inside.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Do you think I like living this way? What do you want of me?!

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: We did. It got lost in the shuffle.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: We can't get everything at once. Right now we've got more important demands.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: What's more important than sanitation?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: The safety of the men -- that's more important! Five accidents this week -- all because of speed-up. You're a woman, you don't know what it's like up there.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: First we got to get equality on the job. Then we'll work on these other things. Leave it to the men.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: I see. The men. You'll strike, maybe, for your demands -- but what the wives want, that comes later, always later.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Now don't start talking against the union again.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: What has it got me, your union?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Esperanza, have you forgotten what it was like before the union came?  When Estella was a baby, and we couldn't even afford a doctor when she got sick? It was for our families! We met in graveyards to build that union!

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: All right. Have your strike. I'll have my baby. But no hospital will take me, because I'll be a striker's wife. The store will cut off our credit, and the kids will go hungry. And we'll get behind on the payments again, and then they'll come and take away the radio...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Is that all you care about? That radio? Can't you think of anything except yourself?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: If I think of myself it's because you never think of me. Never. Never. Never...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Stop it! The children are watching. Stop it!

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Never... never... never!

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Aaah, what's the use?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: I did not mean to weep again. Why should I weep for joy?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: I'm a fool.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: No, no ...

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Was it expensive, the beer?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Antonio paid for it.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Forgive me ... for saying you never thought of me.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: I did forget. Luís told me.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: It's nothing. Just a little catch ...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Mother of God ...have mercy ...

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Have mercy on this child ... let this child live ...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: A fighter, huh?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: He was born fighting. And born hungry.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Drink, drink, Juanito. You'll never have it so good.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: He'll have it good. Some day.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: What were they saying? About you? In there?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: They say I am no good to you.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: You are no good to me -- in jail.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: I'd lie on my cot in the cell and I couldn't sleep with the bugs and the stink and the heat. And I'd say to myself, think of something nice. Something beautiful. And then I'd think of you. And my heart would pound against the cot for love of you.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Not just Juanito. You'll have it good too, Esperanza. We're going to win this strike.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: What makes you so sure?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Because if we lose, we lose more than a strike. We lose the union. And the men know this. And if we win, we win more than a few demands. We win...  ... something bigger. Hope. Hope for our kids. Juanito can't grow strong on milk alone.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Let them take it!

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Over my dead body.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: I don't want your dead body. I don't want you back in jail either.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: But it's yours. I won't let them ...

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Can't you see they want to start a fight so that they can lock you all up at one time?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: It's not fair ... I should be there with them. After all, I'm the one who got the women the vote.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: But the motion passed. It's ... it's not democratic of you to ...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: The union don't run my house.  Those Anglo dames stirred you up to make fools of yourselves -- but you don't see any of them down there.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Yes, I do. There's Ruth Barnes.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: She's the organizer's, wife. She's got to be there.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: NO, she wants to be there.  And there's Mrs. Kalinsky.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: There's Jenkins' wife. You don't see her on no picket line.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Anglo husbands can also be backward.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Can be what?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Backward.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You all right?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Must've been some experience for you, huh?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: I guess you got enough today to last a lifetime, huh?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: I'm going back tomorrow.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You might get hurt.  Listen, if you think I'm gonna play nursemaid from now on, you're crazy ... I've had these kids all day!

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: I've had them since the day they were born.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: I'm telling you. I don't stay home with these kids tomorrow.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Okay. Then, tomorrow, I take the kids with me to the picket line.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: How do you feel?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: I'm okay. But it's nice to be home.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Four nights. How did you sleep?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: We raised such a fuss they finally brought cots in.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Did you have to sign a pledge? Not to go back to the line?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: No, no ... we wouldn't do it.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: But if you go back they'll lock you up again.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: No, no ... the Sheriff had enough of us. We drove him crazy.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: We've got to have a talk, you and me.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: All right, but later. I've got a meeting now.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: A meeting?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Yes. To plan for the picket line tomorrow.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: I waited up till midnight.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You weren't waiting for me.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: That meeting only lasted ten minutes.  The first night I'm home, and you run to the beer parlor. What is it? Can't you bear the sight of me?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Be still ...

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: But you wanted to talk. Tell me.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Tell me.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: We can't go on this way. I just can't go on living with you. Not this way.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: No. We can't can't go on this way. We can't go back to the old way either.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Hunting.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Sun up.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Alone?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Ramón -- you can't.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Why not? I'm not needed here.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: But you are needed. Especially now -- with most of the other men away. You're captain of the stand-by squad.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Sure, the standby squad. Stand-by for the funeral.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Whose funeral? We're doing all right. There hasn't been a scab near the picket line for three days.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: And you know why? Because the company knows they can starve us out -- even if it takes another two, three months. What's it to them if the mine's shut down a little longer?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: It's a lot to them. They'd do anything to open that mine.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Aah! They've got other mines. You don't see the larger picture.  They've got millions. Millions. They can outlast us, and they know it.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: You mean you're ready to give up?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Who said anything about giving up? I'll never go back to the company on my knees. Never.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Ramón were not getting weaker. We're stronger than ever before.  They're getting weaker. They thought they could break our picket line. And they failed. And now they can't win unless they pull off something big, and pull it off fast.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: I don't know. But I can feel it coming. It's like ... like a lull before the storm. Charley Vidal says ...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Charley Vidal says!  Don't throw Charley Vidal up to me!

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Charley's my friend. I need friends.  Why are you afraid to have me as your friend?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: No, you don't. Have you learned nothing from this strike? Why are you afraid to have me at your side? Do you still think you can have dignity only if I have none?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You talk of dignity? After what you've been doing?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Yes. I talk of dignity. The Anglo bosses look down on you, and you hate them for it. "Stay in your place, you dirty Mexican" -- that's what they tell you. But why must you say to me, "Stay in your place." Do you feel better having someone lower than you?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Shut up, you're talking crazy.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: Whose neck shall I stand on, to make me feel superior? And what will I get out of it? I don't want anything lower than I am. I'm low enough already. I want to rise. And push everything up with me as I go ...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Will you be still?

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: And if you can't understand this you're a fool -- because you can't win this strike without me! You can't win anything without me!

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: This is what we've been waiting for.

turns.speaker: ESPERANZA
turns.text: What are you saying?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: This means they've given up trying to break the picket line.  Now we can all fight together -- all of us.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Why didn't you support her? You're the worst of the lot.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: But honey ...

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Or why don't you just put a sign outside? "No dogs or women allowed!"

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We can't think of them just as housewives -- but as allies. And we've got to treat them as such.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Look who's talking! The Great White Father, and World's Champion of Women's Rights.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Aw, cut it out, Ruth.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Me, I'm a camp follower -- following this organizer from one mining camp to another -- Montana, Colorado, Idaho. But did he ever think to organize the women? No. Wives don't count in the Anglo locals either.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Don't horse me. Price of zinc's never been higher. They don't want no strike -- not with their war boom on.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Then why's the company hanging tough? They've signed contracts with other locals -- why not this one?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Because most of us here are Mexican- Americans! Because we want equality with Anglo miners -- the same pay, the same conditions.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Exactly. And equality's the one thing the bosses can't afford. The biggest club they have over the Anglo locals is, "Well -- at least you get more than the Mexicans."

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Okay, so discrimination hurts the Anglo too, but it hurts me more. And I've had enough of it!

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Hear those deputies slugged 'Cente.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah. Lots of provocation lately. They figure if they can lock up the leadership on some phony riot charge, maybe they can bust the strike.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Go on. Spill it.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Well, you're the organizer. You work out strike strategy -- and most of the time you're dead right. But when you figure everything the rank-and-file's to do down to the last detail, you don't give us anything to think about. You afraid we're too lazy to take initiative?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You know I don't think that.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Maybe not. But there's another thing ... like when you came in tonight --  I heard you ask your wife, "Who's that? His grandfather?"

turns.speaker: HARTWELL
turns.text: That's all right -- it's no secret. My name's Hartwell. I'm from the company's Eastern office.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You mean Delaware?

turns.speaker: HARTWELL
turns.text: No. New York.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: New York? You're not the Company President by any chance?

turns.speaker: HARTWELL
turns.text: No ...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Too bad. The men've always wanted to get a look at the President.  But you've come out here to settle the strike?

turns.speaker: HARTWELL
turns.text: Well, if that's possible ...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: It's possible. Just negotiate.

turns.speaker: HARTWELL
turns.text: Are we talking to a union spokesman?

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: What are you doing here?  Something wrong with Mama?

turns.speaker: LUIS
turns.text: I thought maybe you forgot...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Forgot what?

turns.speaker: LUIS
turns.text: It's Mama's Saint's Day.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Luís! Come down here!

turns.speaker: LUIS
turns.text: Papa! We seen 'em! Two scabs! Over there!

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Where's your mama?

turns.speaker: LUIS
turns.text: She's coming. Charley Vidal gave her a lift.

turns.speaker: LUIS
turns.text: Boy! Did you see the way Mama whopped that deputy with her shoe? Knocked the gun right out ...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: I don't want you hanging around there, hear?

turns.speaker: LUIS
turns.text: Papa, can't I leave now? There's a meeting of the Junior Shop Stewards ...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: The what!

turns.speaker: LUIS
turns.text: The Junior Shop Stewards. There's lots of ways we can help.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Don't I have enough troubles without them shipping you off to reform school?

turns.speaker: LUIS
turns.text: But Papa -- you need all the help you can get.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You've got to help around the house!

turns.speaker: LUIS
turns.text: But you've got me doing everything. Mama never used to make me dry the ...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You should have helped her without being asked.

turns.speaker: SEBASTIAN
turns.text: Ramón ... listen for the love of God ...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You ... You ... I'd expect it of an Anglo, yes ... but you ...

turns.speaker: SEBASTIAN
turns.text: Ramón ... listen to me ... I'm in a	jam ... I had to get a job ...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You Judas ... blood-sucker ...

turns.speaker: SEBASTIAN
turns.text: Ramón -- listen my kids ...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Tú! Traidor a tu gente! Rompehuelga! Desgraciado!

turns.speaker: SEBASTIAN
turns.text: My kids don't have enough to eat!

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You think my kids have enough to eat, you rat?

turns.speaker: SEBASTIAN
turns.text: I know, it's wrong. Just let me go. I'll leave town ... just let me go.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: You think I was going to work you over? I wouldn't dirty my hands with you ...

turns.speaker: SAL
turns.text: But you don't pull a strike when the bosses want it -- so they can smash your union. You wait till you're ready, so you can win.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Do the bosses wait? No sanitation. So my kids get sick. Does the company doctor wait? Twenty bucks. So we miss one payment on the radio I bought for my wife. Does the company store wait? "Pay -- or we take it away." Why they in such a hurry, the bosses' store? They're trying to scare us, that's why -- to make us afraid to move. To hang on to what we got -- and like it! Well, I don't like it I'm not scared ... and I'm fed up -- to here!

turns.speaker: SAL
turns.text: And another thing. Your attitude toward Anglos. If you're gonna be a leader ...

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: What attitude?

turns.speaker: SAL
turns.text: You lump them all together -- Anglo workers and Anglo bosses.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: He's a guest in my house, isn't he?

turns.speaker: SAL
turns.text: Sure. But you want the truth? You're even suspicious of him.

turns.speaker: RAMÓN
turns.text: Maybe. I think he's got a few things to learn about our people.

turns.speaker: BO
turns.text: What you want to do is go back the way you came and make a left at the bottom. It'll take you right to the highway.

turns.speaker: DANNY/TOM
turns.text: That's it?

turns.speaker: BO
turns.text: Are you Australian?

turns.speaker: DANNY/TOM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BO
turns.text: Good. I fucking hate Australians.

turns.speaker: DANNY/TOM
turns.text: You got a bathroom I can use before we hit the road?

turns.speaker: BO
turns.text: Yeah? First door on the right. It ain't that dirty.  Just kinda' filthy is all.

turns.speaker: DANNY/TOM
turns.text: You mind?

turns.speaker: BO
turns.text: No, I don't mind.  That's how come I told you about it.

turns.speaker: DANNY/TOM
turns.text: I was talking to my wife.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Bobby?

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Shhh.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: The spiders.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Jimmy, Jimmy, Jimmy, Jimmy. Rhymes with Simmy.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: What can I do for you?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Um, coupla' eight balls oughta do us.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Come on.  Ease off the girl.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Fuck man. Come on, Bobby.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Bobby, Bobby, Bobby.  Rhymes with ...

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: All I saw was the headlights. The high beams were on.

turns.speaker: BOOKMAN
turns.text: Not even a guess?

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Yeah, but he was in silhouette.

turns.speaker: BOOKMAN
turns.text: How about in the house?

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: They were wearing ski masks. I told you all of this.

turns.speaker: BOOKMAN
turns.text: Did you see his hair color?

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: No, Why?

turns.speaker: BOOKMAN
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Nothing, I'm trying to remember...

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Ride 'em cowboy)

turns.speaker: BUBBA
turns.text: You like that?

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Who wouldn't?

turns.speaker: BUBBA
turns.text: First rate, ain't it?

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: It's downright classy is what it is.

turns.speaker: BUBBA
turns.text: I wanna do a small buy first.  Ten thousand.  We'll see how it goes.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Why? The guys is ready to deal now.

turns.speaker: BUBBA
turns.text: Because I don't know him and I don't really know you, partner.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Now that's down-right insulting.

turns.speaker: BUBBA
turns.text: I'll have to live with that.  My money my risk, my rules.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: I guess I don't have a hell of a lot of choice.

turns.speaker: BUBBA
turns.text: Get used to it.  You're in a very tenuous position on the food chain, hoss.

turns.speaker: BUBBA
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Everything go?

turns.speaker: BUBBA
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Just make sure you come alone. This guy won't like any surprises

turns.speaker: BUBBA
turns.text: I ain't a idiot, asshole.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: I'll see you tonight.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Look...I'd like to help you out ... but I really don't want to get involved.

turns.speaker: COLETTE
turns.text: I understand. Thanks anyway.

turns.speaker: COLETTE
turns.text: Jesus, I look like a raccoon.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: I was thinking Alice Cooper.

turns.speaker: COLETTE
turns.text: Oh God.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Come on, cheer up. It could be worse.

turns.speaker: COLETTE
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: I don't know .... you could be staking your financial future on stealing Bob Hope's stool specimen.

turns.speaker: COLETTE
turns.text: What about the guy on the very bottom?

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Leave me out of this.

turns.speaker: COLETTE
turns.text: That bad, huh?

turns.speaker: COLETTE
turns.text: Could be worse.  Oh sorry, forgot who I was talking to.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Ouch.

turns.speaker: COLETTE
turns.text: Don't worry, he's probably passed out with his head in the toilet by now.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: This man sounds like a real catch.

turns.speaker: COLETTE
turns.text: Oh, he's a keeper all right.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Colette ...
